description: In this series, we will take a look at creating functions as a way to collect logic into a reusable chunk. If you want to explore how to create and utilize functions to make your code more readable and maintainable, then join us there!
descriptionMD: In this series, we will take a look at creating functions as a way to collect logic into a reusable chunk. If you want to explore how to create and utilize functions to make your code more readable and maintainable, then join us there!
name: Abstracting with Functions
subtitle: Reusing code one piece at a time

episodes.description: In this series, we will take a look at creating functions as a way to collect logic into a reusable chunk. If you want to explore how to create and utilize functions to make your code more readable and maintainable, then join us there!
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.083 --> 00:00:05.829
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.829 --> 00:00:07.790
Hello and thank you for watching DevProTV.

3
00:00:07.790 --> 00:00:11.810
We are with Justin Dennison talking
about abstracting with functions.

4
00:00:11.810 --> 00:00:14.910
Justin, tell us about this course.
>> So this course is meant to give a you

5
00:00:14.910 --> 00:00:18.370
a little bit of a mental picture
of what a function is, right?

6
00:00:18.370 --> 00:00:19.320
That's to start out.

7
00:00:19.320 --> 00:00:24.740
But our real main goal is to talk about
all the nuances that crop up in Python

8
00:00:24.740 --> 00:00:25.720
when you're creating a function.

9
00:00:25.720 --> 00:00:28.990
So we're gonna be looking at keywords,
at some of the syntax and

10
00:00:28.990 --> 00:00:33.450
then looking at the difference between
positional and keyword argument.

11
00:00:33.450 --> 00:00:36.960
How those all come into play when we're
creating functions that we're going

12
00:00:36.960 --> 00:00:39.580
to reuse later.
>> Now who is this show targeted

13
00:00:39.580 --> 00:00:40.210
toward?
>> So

14
00:00:40.210 --> 00:00:43.770
this is someone who is getting started
in Python and well programming.

15
00:00:43.770 --> 00:00:46.672
The same concepts kind of apply
throughout the programming.

16
00:00:46.672 --> 00:00:48.920
And we're gonna focus on
Python in particular.

17
00:00:48.920 --> 00:00:52.619
If you've ever created a function or
you have some things where your like,

18
00:00:52.619 --> 00:00:55.745
I don't really know what this is,
then this course is for you.

19
00:00:55.745 --> 00:00:59.197
Because well, this is meant to
be a getting started kind of

20
00:00:59.197 --> 00:01:01.885
endeavor.
>> Is there a certification involved in

21
00:01:01.885 --> 00:01:02.665
the course?
>> No,

22
00:01:02.665 --> 00:01:05.125
this is more about powering up our skills.

23
00:01:05.125 --> 00:01:08.375
Learning a little more so
we're better programmers incrementally.

24
00:01:08.375 --> 00:01:09.645
We keep moving forward and

25
00:01:09.645 --> 00:01:11.325
getting better every day.
>> And

26
00:01:11.325 --> 00:01:14.065
I know you've already touched on it,
but what topics are covered

27
00:01:14.065 --> 00:01:15.885
in abstracting with functions?
>> So,

28
00:01:15.885 --> 00:01:19.930
how to create a function,
the keywords associated with a function.

29
00:01:19.930 --> 00:01:23.890
Positional parameters,
how to use multiple positional parameters.

30
00:01:23.890 --> 00:01:25.140
What are keyword arguments?

31
00:01:25.140 --> 00:01:27.120
How to use multiple keyword arguments.

32
00:01:27.120 --> 00:01:29.060
And then how to take all of those things,

33
00:01:29.060 --> 00:01:32.450
put them together to get
really complex functions.

34
00:01:32.450 --> 00:01:35.840
Spoiler alert,
I actually recommend against those.

35
00:01:35.840 --> 00:01:39.440
But so you'll know when you're reading
other people's code, your own code.

36
00:01:39.440 --> 00:01:43.770
Code from six months ago or you're
reading code in the future you'll go,

37
00:01:43.770 --> 00:01:44.600
I know what that means.

38
00:01:44.600 --> 00:01:47.740
So that's our main goal.
>> Thanks Justin, you do a great job.

39
00:01:47.740 --> 00:01:50.820
And if abstracting with functions sounds
like something you'd be interested in, and

40
00:01:50.820 --> 00:01:54.030
you should be; make sure to watch every
single episode in the course library,

41
00:01:54.030 --> 00:01:54.860
you'll be gald you did.

42
00:01:54.860 --> 00:01:57.945
And thanks for watching DevProTV.

43
00:01:57.945 --> 00:02:03.134
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Aubri and Ronnie discuss the purpose and place fo the MAC Address.  They show where to find it and why it's important to networking. The emphasize the importance of getting to know about the binary conversion for any professional networking based certification exam.
episodes.title: What is a Function

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Zach explore creating out first function in Python. Justin discusses the syntax as well as some edge cases to consider when creating a function. Moreover, Justin demonstrates the use of a function to collect programs into a more predictable format.
episodes.title: Creating a Function

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Zach continue expanding on simple functions that can be used to create more complex programs.
episodes.title: Functions without Arguments

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Zach expand the creation of functions by adding a single argument or parameter to the function. Additionally, Justin discusses that parameters can be positional in nature where the order dictates how the function runs.
episodes.title: Functions with a Single Positional Argument

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Zach take a look at functions with a single keyword argument which is like a named or labeled argument. Justin also explores the difference in readability and use of keyword arguments versus positional arguments.
episodes.title: Functions with a Single Keyword Argument

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Zach explore how a function usage can change when there are multiple positional argument including the importance of order.
episodes.title: Functions w/ Multiple Positional Arguments

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Zach discuss and explore the use of multiple keyword arguments in a Python function. Justin further demonstrates how keyword arguments alleviate the ordering and readability concerns that occur in functions.
episodes.title: Functions w/ Multiple Keyword Arguments

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Zach put all of the function types together to explore the use of positional and keyword arguments in more complex contexts.
episodes.title: Fuctions w/ Mixed Arguments
